Lecture 10 Temperature Effects on Reaction Rates Throughout the course so far, we have studied how reaction rates depend on concentrations — through rate laws, integrated rate equations, and the SSA. But concentration is only half the story. Every chemist knows that reactions go faster when you heat them up. In this chapter, we put this observation on a quantitative footing with the Arrhenius equation, which connects the rate constant to temperature and reveals the energetic requirements for a reaction to proceed. 10.1 The Arrhenius Equation In the late 19th century, Svante Arrhenius observed that for many reactions, the rate constant \(k\) increases exponentially with temperature according to: \[\begin{equation} k = A\,\mathrm{e}^{-E_\mathrm{a}/RT} \tag{10.1} \end{equation}\] where: \(A\) is the pre-exponential factor (same units as \(k\)) \(E_\mathrm{a}\) is the activation energy (\(\mathrm{kJ\,mol}^{-1}\)) \(R\) is the gas constant (\(8.314\,\mathrm{J\,K}^{-1}\,\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\)) \(T\) is the absolute temperature (K) The exponential factor \(\mathrm{e}^{-E_\mathrm{a}/RT}\) represents the fraction of molecules with enough energy to react. As \(T\) increases, this fraction grows rapidly — explaining why even modest temperature increases can produce large rate enhancements. Figure 10.1: Rate constant \(k\) as a function of temperature. The exponential relationship means that \(k\) increases steeply with \(T\), with higher \(E_\mathrm{a}\) giving a steeper temperature dependence. 10.2 The Linearised Arrhenius Equation Taking the natural logarithm of Eqn. (10.1): \[\begin{equation} \ln k = \ln A - \frac{E_\mathrm{a}}{R} \cdot \frac{1}{T} \tag{10.2} \end{equation}\] This is the equation of a straight line with \(\ln k\) on the \(y\)-axis and \(1/T\) on the \(x\)-axis: Slope \(= -E_\mathrm{a}/R\) \(y\)-intercept \(= \ln A\) An Arrhenius plot of \(\ln k\) versus \(1/T\) is therefore the standard graphical method for determining activation energies. A steeper (more negative) slope indicates a larger activation energy — the reaction is more sensitive to temperature. Figure 10.2: Arrhenius plot: \(\ln k\) versus \(1/T\). The slope gives \(-E_\mathrm{a}/R\) and the \(y\)-intercept gives \(\ln A\). A steeper slope corresponds to a higher activation energy. The line of best fit is used to extract \(E_\mathrm{a}\) and \(A\) from experimental data. 10.3 Physical Meaning of the Arrhenius Parameters 10.3.1 The Activation Energy (\(E_\mathrm{a}\)) The activation energy represents an energy threshold that must be exceeded for reactants to transform into products. We can visualise this using a reaction coordinate diagram: Figure 10.3: Reaction coordinate diagram showing the energy profile along the reaction pathway. The activation energy \(E_\mathrm{a}\) is the height of the energy barrier separating reactants from products. The transition state sits at the top of the barrier. The energy difference \(\Delta E_\mathrm{r}\) between reactants and products determines the thermodynamics; \(E_\mathrm{a}\) determines the kinetics. At temperature \(T\), molecules have a distribution of kinetic energies. Only those with energy exceeding \(E_\mathrm{a}\) can surmount the barrier and react. The Boltzmann factor \(\mathrm{e}^{-E_\mathrm{a}/RT}\) gives the fraction of molecules that meet this criterion. As \(T\) increases, the energy distribution broadens and a larger fraction of molecules can react — which is why the rate increases. 10.3.2 The Pre-Exponential Factor (\(A\)) The pre-exponential factor represents the rate constant that would be observed if the energy barrier were absent (\(E_\mathrm{a} = 0\)). It encapsulates all the non-energetic factors that affect the reaction rate: The frequency of molecular collisions The probability that colliding molecules have the correct orientation Other geometric and steric factors For bimolecular reactions, \(A\) is typically in the range \(10^{9}\)–\(10^{11}\,\mathrm{dm}^3\,\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\,\mathrm{s}^{-1}\), reflecting the collision frequency modified by steric requirements. 10.4 Determining Arrhenius Parameters 10.4.1 From an Arrhenius Plot The most common approach is to measure \(k\) at several temperatures, plot \(\ln k\) versus \(1/T\), and determine \(E_\mathrm{a}\) from the slope and \(A\) from the intercept. In practice, the \(y\)-intercept (\(\ln A\)) corresponds to \(1/T = 0\) (infinite temperature), which lies far outside the experimental data range. A more reliable method is to use the slope together with a point on the fitted line to calculate \(A\) without extrapolation. 10.4.2 The Two-Temperature Formula When rate constants are known at just two temperatures, the activation energy can be determined directly. Subtracting the Arrhenius equation at \(T_1\) from that at \(T_2\): \[\begin{equation} \ln\frac{k_2}{k_1} = \frac{E_\mathrm{a}}{R}\left(\frac{1}{T_1} - \frac{1}{T_2}\right) \tag{10.3} \end{equation}\] This is a very practical result: given \(k\) at two temperatures, we can find \(E_\mathrm{a}\) without knowing \(A\). Rearranging: \[E_\mathrm{a} = \frac{R\ln(k_2/k_1)}{1/T_1 - 1/T_2}\] The same equation can be used in reverse: given \(E_\mathrm{a}\) and \(k\) at one temperature, we can predict \(k\) at another temperature. A rough rule of thumb for reactions with typical activation energies (\(\sim 50\,\mathrm{kJ\,mol}^{-1}\)) is that the rate approximately doubles for every \(10\,\mathrm{K}\) increase in temperature near room temperature — though the exact factor depends on \(E_\mathrm{a}\). You should be able to: Use the Arrhenius equation to construct an Arrhenius plot and extract \(E_\mathrm{a}\) and \(A\), and apply the two-temperature formula (Eqn. (10.3)) to calculate \(E_\mathrm{a}\) from rate constants at two temperatures or to predict a rate constant at a new temperature. 10.5 Negative Activation Energies and Non-Arrhenius Behaviour 10.5.1 Negative Activation Energies For most reactions, \(E_\mathrm{a} > 0\) and the rate increases with temperature. But some reactions display the opposite behaviour — their rates decrease as temperature rises, corresponding to a negative apparent activation energy. We have already met an example: the oxidation of nitric oxide (Lecture 7): \[2\mathrm{NO} + \mathrm{O_2} \rightarrow 2\mathrm{NO_2}\] This reaction proceeds through a pre-equilibrium mechanism: \[\mathrm{NO} + \mathrm{NO} \underset{k_{-1}}{\stackrel{k_1}{\rightleftharpoons}} (\mathrm{NO})_2 \qquad (\mathrm{NO})_2 + \mathrm{O_2} \xrightarrow{k_2} 2\mathrm{NO_2}\] The observed rate constant is \(k_\mathrm{obs} = k_2 K = k_2 k_1/k_{-1}\). The dimerisation equilibrium is exothermic, so \(K\) decreases with increasing temperature (Le Chatelier’s principle). Although \(k_2\) increases with temperature (it has a positive activation energy), the decrease in \(K\) is faster — so the overall effect is that \(k_\mathrm{obs}\) decreases. The Arrhenius plot has a positive slope, corresponding to a negative apparent \(E_\mathrm{a}\). A negative activation energy does not mean there is no energy barrier for the individual elementary steps — each step has a positive \(E_\mathrm{a}\). Rather, the observed \(E_\mathrm{a}\) for the overall reaction is a combination of the activation energies for the individual steps and the enthalpy change of the pre-equilibrium step. Figure 10.4: Arrhenius plot for a reaction with negative apparent activation energy (positive slope), such as the oxidation of NO. The rate decreases with increasing temperature because the exothermic pre-equilibrium shifts to the left faster than the slow step accelerates. You should be able to: Explain why the NO oxidation reaction has a negative apparent activation energy by connecting the temperature dependence of the pre-equilibrium constant to the overall rate. 10.5.2 Non-Arrhenius Behaviour Several situations can produce curved Arrhenius plots — departures from the simple linear relationship between \(\ln k\) and \(1/T\): Competing reaction pathways. When two parallel pathways with different activation energies contribute to the overall rate, the observed rate constant is \(k_\mathrm{obs} = k_1 + k_2\). At low temperatures, the low-\(E_\mathrm{a}\) pathway dominates; at high temperatures, the high-\(E_\mathrm{a}\) pathway takes over. The Arrhenius plot shows two approximately linear regions with different slopes, connected by a curve. Change in rate-determining step. For multi-step mechanisms, the rate-determining step can change with temperature if different steps have different activation energies. Diffusion-limited reactions. When the reaction rate approaches the diffusion limit, the temperature dependence weakens because diffusion has a lower activation energy than most chemical steps. Figure 10.5: Non-Arrhenius behaviour: a non-linear Arrhenius plot arising from two competing reaction pathways with different activation energies. The observed rate constant \(k_\mathrm{obs} = k_1 + k_2\) shows two approximately linear regimes connected by a curve, as the dominant pathway changes with temperature. You should be able to: Describe how competing reaction pathways with different activation energies can produce a curved Arrhenius plot. 10.6 Key Concepts The Arrhenius equation, \(k = A\,\mathrm{e}^{-E_\mathrm{a}/RT}\), describes how rate constants increase exponentially with temperature. It contains two parameters: the activation energy \(E_\mathrm{a}\) (the energy barrier) and the pre-exponential factor \(A\) (the collision frequency and orientation probability). An Arrhenius plot of \(\ln k\) versus \(1/T\) gives a straight line with slope \(-E_\mathrm{a}/R\) and intercept \(\ln A\). The two-temperature formula, \(\ln(k_2/k_1) = (E_\mathrm{a}/R)(1/T_1 - 1/T_2)\), allows determination of \(E_\mathrm{a}\) from measurements at two temperatures or prediction of \(k\) at a new temperature. Negative apparent activation energies arise in multi-step mechanisms where a pre-equilibrium step is exothermic — the equilibrium constant decreases with temperature faster than the rate constant of the slow step increases. Non-Arrhenius behaviour (curved Arrhenius plots) can arise from competing pathways, changes in the rate-determining step, or diffusion limitations. The Arrhenius equation provides the bridge between macroscopic kinetic measurements (rate constants at different temperatures) and molecular-level understanding (energy barriers and collision dynamics).

B Why Don’t All Bimolecular Reactions Require a Third Body? In Lecture 7, we saw that ozone formation requires a third body to carry away the excess energy released when a new O–O bond forms (Section 6.2). The argument rested on energy and momentum conservation — principles that apply to all molecular collisions. This raises a natural question: if these constraints prevent a simple O + O2 reaction, why do we routinely observe second-order kinetics for other bimolecular reactions? This appendix explores the physical factors that determine whether a reaction can proceed without third-body assistance. The material is not examinable, but it deepens our understanding of why different reactions exhibit different kinetic behaviour. B.1 The Problem: Energy Disposal After Bond Formation When two species collide and form a new bond, the bond energy is released as kinetic energy of the product molecule. Conservation of momentum constrains how this energy is distributed: much of it ends up as vibration along the newly formed bond. If this vibrational energy exceeds the bond dissociation energy, the product flies apart again before it can be observed — the reaction effectively has not occurred. For ozone, the situation is extreme. Formation of the O–O bond releases approximately \(107\,\mathrm{kJ\,mol}^{-1}\), and ozone — a triatomic molecule — has only three vibrational modes to absorb this energy. The newly formed bond is so vibrationally excited that dissociation is inevitable without a third body to carry away the excess. B.2 Why Most Reactions Avoid This Problem Several factors, often acting in combination, allow most bimolecular reactions to manage the released energy without requiring third-body intervention. Activation barriers redirect energy flow. Most reactions have an activation energy barrier, creating a transition state that the system must pass through. The descent from this saddle point on the potential energy surface distributes energy across multiple degrees of freedom — vibrational, rotational, and translational — rather than concentrating it in a single bond. Ozone formation is barrierless, so this redistribution mechanism is absent. Larger molecules have more vibrational modes. A non-linear molecule with \(N\) atoms has \(3N - 6\) vibrational modes. For ozone (\(N = 3\)), this gives only 3 modes; for a molecule with 10 atoms, it gives 24. The same amount of released energy spreads across many more modes, reducing the excitation in any single bond below the dissociation threshold. Exchange reactions balance energy flow. Many bimolecular reactions involve simultaneous bond breaking and bond formation: \[\mathrm{A} + \mathrm{BC} \rightarrow \mathrm{AB} + \mathrm{C}\] The energy required to break the B–C bond partially offsets the energy released by forming the A–B bond. This reduces the net energy that the products must accommodate. Ozone formation, by contrast, is a pure association reaction with no offsetting bond breaking. B.3 A Spectrum of Behaviour Rather than a sharp divide, reactions span a spectrum. The likelihood of requiring third-body stabilisation increases with: Decreasing activation barrier height Increasing reaction exothermicity Decreasing molecular complexity (fewer vibrational modes) Pure association character (no bond breaking to offset energy release) Ozone formation sits at the extreme end of this spectrum — highly exothermic, barrierless, forming a small molecule with few internal degrees of freedom. Most bimolecular reactions we encounter in this course have some combination of activation barriers, moderate energy release, and greater molecular complexity that allows them to proceed as straightforward second-order processes. This explains an observation from Lecture 1: termolecular processes are rare, and apparent third-order kinetics usually arise from sequential bimolecular steps (as in the NO oxidation mechanism discussed in Lecture 7) rather than genuine three-body collisions.

C Negative Reaction Orders In Lecture 1, we defined the order of a reaction with respect to a given species as the exponent in the rate law. For the reactions we encounter in the main lectures, these exponents are positive integers or zero: increasing a reactant’s concentration either speeds up the reaction or has no effect. In some reactions, however, increasing the concentration of a particular species slows down the reaction. This unusual behaviour corresponds to a negative reaction order. This appendix explores how negative orders arise from underlying mechanisms. The material is not examinable, but it illustrates an important theme of the course: macroscopic rate laws encode information about microscopic mechanisms. C.1 What Does a Negative Order Mean? When a species X appears with a negative order \(n\) in a rate law: \[
u =  rac{k[\mathrm{A}]^a[\mathrm{B}]^b}{[\mathrm{X}]^n}\] increasing \([\mathrm{X}]\) decreases the reaction rate. The species X effectively acts as an inhibitor rather than a promoter of the reaction. Negative orders cannot arise from a single elementary step — they always signal a complex, multi-step mechanism in which the species interferes with one or more productive reaction pathways. C.2 Example 1: Product Inhibition in H2 + Br2 \(ightarrow\) 2HBr The formation of hydrogen bromide — a chain reaction discussed in detail in Lecture 9 — provides a classic example of product inhibition. The empirical rate law is: \[
u =  rac{k[\mathrm{H_2}][\mathrm{Br_2}]^{1/2}}{1 + k'[\mathrm{HBr}]/[\mathrm{Br_2}]}\] At high concentrations of HBr (specifically when \(k'[\mathrm{HBr}]/[\mathrm{Br_2}] \gg 1\)), this simplifies to: \[
u \approx  rac{k[\mathrm{H_2}][\mathrm{Br_2}]^{3/2}}{k'[\mathrm{HBr}]}\] Here, HBr has an effective order of \(-1\). The very product we are trying to make inhibits its own formation. The origin lies in the chain mechanism. The key propagation steps produce HBr via reactive H\(^{ ullet}\) radicals (Lecture 9), but HBr can also react with these same radicals: \[\mathrm{H}^{ ullet} + \mathrm{HBr} ightarrow \mathrm{Br}^{ ullet} + \mathrm{H_2}\] This chain inhibition step consumes the very intermediates needed for product formation. The more HBr present, the more this reverse reaction competes with productive chain propagation, slowing the net rate. This is a general principle in chain kinetics: anything that consumes or deactivates chain-carrying intermediates produces negative kinetic behaviour. C.3 Example 2: Competitive Adsorption in Surface Reactions Surface-catalysed reactions provide another important class of systems with negative orders, closely related to the Langmuir adsorption model discussed in Lecture 8. Unlike homogeneous reactions, surface processes require that reactants first adsorb onto the catalyst before they can react. The catalyst surface has a limited number of active sites, creating the potential for competition. For a typical surface reaction following the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism: \(\mathrm{A}_{(\mathrm{g})} + {*} ightleftharpoons \mathrm{A}{*}\) (A adsorbs on an empty site \({*}\)) \(\mathrm{B}_{(\mathrm{g})} + {*} ightleftharpoons \mathrm{B}{*}\) (B adsorbs on an empty site \({*}\)) \(\mathrm{A}{*} + \mathrm{B}{*} ightarrow 	ext{products} + 2{*}\) (reaction between adsorbed species) The rate depends on having both A and B adsorbed on adjacent sites. If one species (say B) adsorbs much more strongly, or is present at very high pressure, it can monopolise the surface sites. Increasing the pressure of B then actually decreases the reaction rate, because B blocks the sites that A needs. This leads to a negative apparent order in B at high pressures, despite B being an essential reactant. This site-blocking effect is commonly observed in industrial catalysis. For example, in CO oxidation on platinum, excess CO can poison the catalyst by blocking oxygen adsorption sites. The mathematical framework from Lecture 8 — where the Langmuir isotherm describes surface coverage as a function of pressure — provides the quantitative basis for understanding these effects. C.4 Recognising Negative Orders Negative orders often appear in disguised forms within rate expressions: Denominator terms: Any concentration appearing in the denominator has a negative effective order, whether directly (e.g., \(k[\mathrm{A}]/[\mathrm{X}]\)) or within inhibition factors (e.g., \(k[\mathrm{A}]/(1 + K[\mathrm{X}])\)). Saturation behaviour: Rates that plateau or decrease with increasing concentration suggest competitive effects leading to negative orders in the high-concentration limit. The common thread is that negative orders arise when a species participates in the overall mechanism in ways that hinder rather than help the net forward reaction — whether by consuming reactive intermediates, blocking active sites, or driving reverse reactions.
